programme.title: Someone They Knew with Tamron Hall
programme.desc: Rosemarie Essa appears to die in a car crash; when police learn this was no more than a low-speed fender bender, they begin to suspect foul play by someone who knew what they were doing.

programme.title: Someone They Knew with Tamron Hall
programme.desc: Ashley Biggs thought it was just another pizza delivery, and didn't know who was waiting on the other end; she didn't come back, and police found the delivery address abandoned, with a pool of blood on the ground.

programme.title: Someone They Knew with Tamron Hall
programme.desc: When teenager Dennis Lewis is killed fighting off home invaders, all police have to go on is a single handprint; when lab results reveal who the print belongs to, no one wants to believe it.

programme.title: The Trials Of Dr. Death
programme.desc: The defense put on an intense cross-examination; the state rested its case in the trial of Doctor Jack Kevorkian; he fought charges of violating the assisted suicide ban in Michigan.

programme.title: The Trials Of Dr. Death
programme.sub-title: Legal Issues Taken Up In Court
programme.desc: According to Dr. Jack Kevorkian both Merian Frederick and doctor Ali Khalili were number nineteen and twenty in his physician-assisted suicide procedures.

programme.title: The Trials Of Dr. Death
programme.desc: A defense called a neurologist to testify in Doctor Jack Kevorkian's trial; he started by laying out his qualifications and credentials; Jurors got to hear from the defense.

programme.title: The Trials Of Dr. Death
programme.desc: A neurologist and author testified as to the emotional and mental state of a person dealing with a terminal illness; that's what Doctor Ali Khalili and Merian Ferguson both faced before they turned to Doctor Jack Kevorkian.

programme.title: The Trials Of Dr. Death
programme.desc: The defense's first witness was a neurologist who was a clear supporter of Dr. Jack Kevorkian's work; he reviewed the medical history of Doctor Ali Khalili and Merian Frederick.

programme.title: The Trials Of Dr. Death
programme.desc: The mental status of Dr. Ali Khalili was called into question; his death was at the center of Dr. Jack Kevorkian's latest trial; jurors heard from a neurologist who gave his diagnosis.

programme.title: The Trials Of Dr. Death
programme.desc: A clinical psychiatrist took the stand explaining to jurors that he felt both Merian Frederick and Dr. Ali Khalili did not want to die per se; Dr. Bernard Carroll evaluated both of them.

programme.title: The Trials Of Dr. Death
programme.desc: Medical experts took the stand; a board-certified internist testifying for the defense; doctors of neurology, internal medicine, and psychiatry all gave their reasons why two of Doctor Jack Kevorkian's patients ended their lives.

programme.title: Nanny Abduction Murder Trial
programme.desc: Dr. Greg Prichard, a forensic psychologist, answered questions under cross-examination. The Defense challenged his claim that Scott Nelson did not suffer from any mental illness at the time he killed Jennifer Fulford.

programme.title: Nanny Abduction Murder Trial
programme.desc: Cross-examination continued on the State's mental health expert who dismissed the diagnosis that the defendant suffered mental illness when he killed Jennifer Fulford.

programme.title: Nanny Abduction Murder Trial
programme.desc: In the State's closing arguments, the prosecutor highlighted key aggravating factors that led to Jennifer Fulford's death. It included a cold, calculated plan for murder and the defendant's violent criminal past.

programme.title: Nanny Abduction Murder Trial
programme.desc: During the State's long closing argument, jurors were retold the timeline of events that led to Jennifer Fulford's murder.

programme.title: Nanny Abduction Murder Trial
programme.desc: Scott Nelson's defense attorney began closing arguments with the claim, This case does not warrant the death penalty. hat's how Scott Nelson's attorney told jurors during closing arguments.

programme.title: Nanny Abduction Murder Trial
programme.desc: Poor cognitive function and impaired brain damage coupled with an abusive childhood were mitigating factors Scott Nelson's defense wanted jurors to consider in his death penalty trial.

programme.title: Killer Or Cover-Up Murder Trial
programme.desc: A forensic scientist on the stand had more to tell the jury about crime scene evidence.

programme.title: Killer Or Cover-Up Murder Trial
programme.sub-title: Explaining The Glass, Plastic, And Hair Found
programme.desc: Maureen Hartnett, the crime scene analyst working this case, got grilled by Karen Read's defense under cross-examination.

programme.title: Killer Or Cover-Up Murder Trial
programme.desc: Prosecutors brought in another analyst who did physical matches on crime scene evidence.

programme.title: Killer Or Cover-Up Murder Trial
programme.desc: For prosecutors, the broken taillight pieces served as proof that Karen Read hit her boyfriend with her SUV and then drove off all while under the influence.

programme.title: Killer Or Cover-Up Murder Trial
programme.desc: The jury listened to detailed testimony about evidence recovered from the snowy crime scene were John O'Keefe was found.

programme.title: Killer Or Cover-Up Murder Trial
programme.desc: Trace evidence was key for the prosecution as it tried to link Karen Read to the murder of her boyfriend, John O'Keefe. So, the State brought in yet another forensic scientist.

programme.title: Someone They Knew with Tamron Hall
programme.desc: HS football coach Ed Thomas is a legend in Parkersburg, Iowa, who had mentored multiple players into the NFL, and kids even had a poster of him on their walls; when he is gunned down during an early morning workout, the entire town is shocked.

programme.title: Someone They Knew with Tamron Hall
programme.desc: On the surface the Carters seemed like a happy family of Iowa farmers, but when they discover Shirley Carter shot to death in her kitchen, the family begins pointing fingers at each other.
